content:
I believe that the largest concern we're going to have with an official move to Zulip will be the potential to loose connection with some people who are connected via Gitter but might not be motivated to set up/move to a new service.

Gitter says that we have 206 people with Gitter accounts. It appears as if 16 have already tested Zulip (set up accounts here) in just the last 24 hours. That is a good sign.
I think a lot of those 206 people were early in on the initial activity, but are no longer active/interested in Backdrop.
(Which means that I'm not sure that's a good metric to base future activity on.)

@StPaulTim True, but it might be like when Backdrop had to cull their mailing list - it's really only those who aren't/haven't been active that we'll be 'losing'. And even then, if they ever do check in on Gitter there'll be a message about having moved official support, etc. here, and I'm sure there'll still be people (like myself) who'll be willing to check Gitter regularly and continue to provide 'unofficial' support there.

One other implication is that, from what I've seen/understand, we'll lose the ability to have these conversations read by anyone online without an account. E.g. you can go here https://gitter.im/backdrop/backdrop-issues and read all conversations without signing in, but the same doesn't seem to be true of https://backdrop.zulipchat.com/ (unless there's a setting for that that we need to enable...?)

That's true. I've done a little digging around and I don't see any way to make the entire conversation public (visible to users without an account). I wonder how useful that feature is.

I can imagine that quite a few people peek into our Gitter room without creating accounts. But, I'm not sure how useful that really is, other than giving them the opportunity to check us out, before creating an account. I wonder if using Zulip would have a positive or negative effect on NEW users joining the chat community.

Yeah, just searched through their help (and by 'searched' I mean 'browsed', because there's no search option!) and couldn't see anything about making it public for anonymous users. But I'm also not sure if that's a negative implication (I for one was a little concerned when I was talking about moving back to Australia in Gitter, but hadn't told my boss here yet...) :smile:

The docs seem to refer to a "guest" role/permission but I'm not 100% sure how that role works (it may still require registration and log in):
https://zulipchat.com/help/stream-permissions

But if Zulip becomes the live chat and people are encouraged to post/summarize good topics in the (public) forum, it may be okay that it's not all immediately browsable without registering.

Stream privacy settings (Zulip Help Center)
Streams are similar to chatrooms, IRC channels, or email lists in that they determine who receives a message. There are three types of streams in Zulip. | Public: Anyone other than guests can join, and anyone (other than guests) can view the complete message history without joining. | Private, shared history: You must be added by a member of the stream. The complete message history is available as soon as you are added. | Private, protected history: You must be added by a member of the stream. You only have access to the messages that are sent after you are added.
I already like how topics are making it easier for me to catch up on conversations.
Gitter now has threaded replies, but it seems it's buggy and people are struggling with it... New feature kinks, or the beginning of the end for Gitter...?
I find threaded replies pretty useless too, even in Slack. Pain in the butt to find anything
Which is why I like that we're trying Zulip so people get an idea of the difference
Yes, I think it shows when something is designed a certain way out-of-the-box, not tacked on afterwards.

Ah ha! Just came across this as a way to archive Zulip chats as HTML (e.g. make them available to browse/index publicly): https://github.com/zulip/zulip-archive And using GitHub Actions you can automate it so the archive stays up-to-date.

zulip/zulip-archive
A tool for archiving and displaying Zulip chat channels. - zulip/zulip-archive
I'm really liking how I can click through a topic at a time to catch up.
